children.text:
For program1.py:
We are given n, q and a list of prices.
children.label: code_analysis

children.text: We sort the prices in descending order and compute a prefix sum array s.
children.label: high_level_plan

children.text:
For each query (x, y): 
  The customer must purchase at least x items.
children.label: mental_execution

children.text:
To maximize the free value (which is the sum of the y cheapest items in the purchase), 
  the customer would choose exactly x items (because adding more expensive items might push some cheaper ones to be free, but note: the free items are the y cheapest in the purchase).
children.label: mental_execution

children.text: However, note that the free items are the y cheapest. So we want to maximize the sum of the y cheapest in a set of x items. How?
children.label: high_level_plan

children.text: We can choose the x items arbitrarily.
children.label: high_level_plan

children.text: The best strategy is to take the x items that are as expensive as possible? But note: the free items are the cheapest ones. So if we take the most expensive x items, then the cheapest y among them will be the last y in our sorted descending list?
children.label: high_level_plan

children.text:
Actually, in descending order, the cheapest y in the set of x would be the last y in the set (which are the smallest ones in the set). Since we have sorted in descending order: 
      p[0] >= p[1] >= ... >= p[n-1]

  If we take the top x items: indices 0 to x-1, then the cheapest y items in this set are the last y of these, i.e., from index x-y to x-1? But note: in descending order, the last y in the segment [0, x-1] are the smallest in that segment.
children.label: mental_execution

children.text: However, we can also consider: what if we skip some expensive items? But note: if we skip an expensive item, we have to take a cheaper one. Then the set of purchased items would have a cheaper set of items, and the free ones would be even cheaper? But observe: we want the sum of the free items to be as large as possible.

children.text: The optimal strategy is to take the most expensive x items.

children.text:
Why?

children.text: - If we replace one of the expensive items with a cheaper one that is not in the top x, then the set of purchased items will have a cheaper item.

tree.original_reasoning:
We are given two programs to complete.

For program1.py:
We are given n, q and a list of prices. We sort the prices in descending order and compute a prefix sum array s.
For each query (x, y): 
  The customer must purchase at least x items. To maximize the free value (which is the sum of the y cheapest items in the purchase), 
  the customer would choose exactly x items (because adding more expensive items might push some cheaper ones to be free, but note: the free items are the y cheapest in the purchase).
  However, note that the free items are the y cheapest. So we want to maximize the sum of the y cheapest in a set of x items.

  How? We can choose the x items arbitrarily. The best strategy is to take the x items that are as expensive as possible? 
  But note: the free items are the cheapest ones. So if we take the most expensive x items, then the cheapest y among them will be the last y in our sorted descending list? 
  Actually, in descending order, the cheapest y in the set of x would be the last y in the set (which are the smallest ones in the set). 

  Since we have sorted in descending order: 
      p[0] >= p[1] >= ... >= p[n-1]

  If we take the top x items: indices 0 to x-1, then the cheapest y items in this set are the last y of these, i.e., from index x-y to x-1? 
  But note: in descending order, the last y in the segment [0, x-1] are the smallest in that segment. 

  However, we can also consider: what if we skip some expensive items? But note: if we skip an expensive item, we have to take a cheaper one. Then the set of purchased items would have a cheaper set of items, and the free ones would be even cheaper? 
  But observe: we want the sum of the free items to be as large as possible. The free items are the y cheapest in the purchase. So we want the y cheapest to be as expensive as possible.

  The optimal strategy is to take the most expensive x items. Why?
    - The free items are the y cheapest. In the set of the top x items, the y cheapest are the last y of these. 
    - If we replace one of the expensive items with a cheaper one that is not in the top x, then the set of purchased items will have a cheaper item. This cheaper item will be one of the free ones (because it is cheaper than the rest). Then the free set would include this cheaper item and we lose the opportunity to have a more expensive item in the free set.

  Therefore, for a query (x, y):
      We take the top x items: indices 0 to x-1 in the sorted descending list.
      The free items are the last y of these, which in the descending order are the ones from index x-y to x-1? 
      Actually, in the segment [0, x-1] (which is the top x), the smallest y are the last y in the segment? 
        But note: the segment [0, x-1] is sorted descending, so the last y are the smallest.

  How to compute the sum of the free items? 
      We have the prefix sum array s for the entire sorted descending array. 
      The prefix sum s[i] is the sum of the first i items (i.e., indices 0 to i-1) in the descending order.

      The entire set of x items: indices 0 to x-1 -> sum = s[x] (because s[0]=0, s[1]=p[0], s[2]=p[0]+p[1], ... s[x]=p[0]+...+p[x-1])
      The free items are the last y of these: which are the items from index x-y to x-1. 
      The sum of these free items = s[x] - s[x-y]   ??? 

      But note: 
          s[x] = p[0] + p[1] + ... + p[x-1]
